G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time with respect to Sophie pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 208, § 29, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as the original custody and parenting-time judgment was issued by this Court on or about March 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time with respect to Sophie pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 208, § 29, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as the original custody and parenting-time judgment was issued by this Court on or about March 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue in the Middlesex Division of the Probate and Family Court is proper because the original Judgment was entered here and the child resides in Middlesex County. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 223, § 1.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 29.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time with respect to Sophie pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 208, § 29, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as the original custody and parenting-time judgment was issued by this Court on or about March 15, 2020.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue in the Middlesex Division of the Probate and Family Court is proper because the original Judgment was entered here and the child resides in Middlesex County. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 223, § 1.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: Massachusetts remains Sophie’s “home state” for purposes of custody determination under the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, G.L. c. 209B, and Massachusetts retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction over the existing custody order.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount concern in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266 (2001); G.L. c. 208, § 31.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 31\u201331A.proposition: The relief requested herein is consistent with the statutory framework for modification of custody and parenting time, including G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 208, §§ 31–31A, and with controlling caselaw such as *Mason v. Coleman*, *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, *Custody of Vaughn*, *Rosenthal v. Maney*, *Murphy v. Murphy*, *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, *Rolde v. Rolde*, and *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a parenting schedule that was reasonable under one set of circumstances may warrant modification when circumstances materially change, particularly where the child’s stability, education, or emotional welfare is affected. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn concerns standards for making explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects in an initial or existing custody arrangement; it does not articulate or apply the standard for *modifying* a parenting schedule based on a material change of circumstances such as impact on stability, education, or emotional welfare. The court focuses on the need for findings under G.L. c. 208, § 31, and the best‑interests analysis in light of domestic violence, not on when changed circumstances warrant modification of a prior schedule. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification principle stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Murphy v. Murphy, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).proposition: The Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a parenting schedule that was reasonable under one set of circumstances may warrant modification when circumstances materially change, particularly where the child’s stability, education, or emotional welfare is affected. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Murphy v. Murphy*, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).
Murphy v. Murphy, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).support_reasoning: Murphy v. Murphy concerns whether a Massachusetts Probate Court should exercise jurisdiction to entertain a custody proceeding when an Arizona custody case (with a temporary order) is already pending. The court mentions ‘material change in circumstances’ only in the context of the standard for modifying a foreign custody decree and the impropriety of simultaneous proceedings, not as a general rule that parenting schedules reasonable under one set of circumstances may be modified after material changes affecting stability, education, or emotional welfare. It does not discuss or decide the merits of modifying an existing parenting schedule based on changed circumstances as described in the proposition.
Murphy v. Murphy, 380 Mass. 454 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “The entire Probate Court hearing in Massachusetts consisted of arguments of counsel and testimony of the wife and her sister. No material change in circumstances was alleged other than the move from Arizona to Massachusetts. In light of the very brief lapse of time between the entry of the Arizona temporary order and the Massachusetts proceeding, it would be most unusual for a material change in circumstances to have occurred. … The party seeking modification of a foreign custody decree is required to show a material change in circumstances. Buchanan v. Buchanan, 353 Mass. 351 (1967).”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 186\u20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting-time judgment is appropriate where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186–87 (2006); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); G.L. c. 208, § 28.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 186\u20.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a modification-of-custody standard case under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The opinion discusses that removal may be ordered only when it is in the child’s best interests and, by reference to the ALI Principles, notes that relocation can constitute a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not articulate or apply the two-prong Massachusetts modification test (material and substantial change plus best interests). The cited pages focus on defining and applying the ‘best interests’ standard for relocation where parents share physical custody, not on the generic standard for modifying a custody or parenting-time judgment.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of a custody or parenting-time judgment is appropriate where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186–87 (2006); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); G.L. c. 208, § 28.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the standard for awarding custody in the first instance, focusing exclusively on the best interests/welfare of the child and the need to weigh all relevant factors. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or parenting-time judgment or the prerequisite of a material and substantial change in circumstances. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the two-part modification standard stated in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). … This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount concern in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266 (2001); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal cases under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and then describes those best interests as the “central question.” It further notes that although the custodial parent’s interests are considered, the best interests of the children “always remain the paramount concern.” This squarely supports the proposition that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody/parenting-time determinations and modifications.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount concern in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266 (2001); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that custody and modification determinations must be guided by the child’s welfare/best interests, and applies that standard both to the modification-of-custody analysis under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and to the removal analysis under Yannas. In discussing modification, the court emphasizes that any change in custody must be necessary in the best interests of the child, and in the removal section it reiterates that the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern, directly supporting the proposition cited.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt:
“Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

“A parent’s request to relocate with a child from the Commonwealth must be ‘grounded on…[t]he best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern….’”}

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that parenting plans must be workable in light of the parties’ actual geography and the child’s school obligations, and that long midweek commutes may be inconsistent with the child’s welfare. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 186–87 (modification appropriate where existing arrangement no longer serves child’s best interests); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: Rolde concerns custody, joint custody, and visitation reductions between parents who live in the same general area (Brookline/Weston); it does not discuss geographic distance, commuting burdens, or the child’s school schedule as constraints on visitation or parenting plans. The visitation discussion focuses on parental conflict and best interests generally, not on travel time or midweek commutes. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that long midweek commutes or geographic impracticality render a parenting plan inconsistent with the child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “We pause merely to touch upon the husband’s claim that the judge ‘cut back so severely on the amount of time that [he] may spend with his children that it now is impossible for him to maintain a meaningful relationship with them.’ There is no error. From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order… ‘[T]he ‘best interests’ of the child[ren] are to be promoted…’”}

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The relief requested herein is consistent with the statutory framework for modification of custody and parenting time, including G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 208, §§ 31–31A, and with controlling caselaw such as *Mason v. Coleman*, *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, *Custody of Vaughn*, *Rosenthal v. Maney*, *Murphy v. Murphy*, *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, *Rolde v. Rolde*, and *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: Vilakazi v. Maxie is a pre-209C, pre-§§ 31–31A custody case that discusses the general best-interests standard, appellate review of Probate Court custody decrees, and notes in passing that custody orders are subject to future modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and § 30. It does not analyze or articulate the modern statutory framework for modification of custody and parenting time, nor does it provide substantive construction of § 28, § 31, § 31A, or 209C § 20. The case is therefore at most tangentially relevant and does not meaningfully support the broad proposition that the requested relief is consistent with the current modification framework and controlling caselaw.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion. As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, Palmer v. Palmer, 357 Mass. 764 (1970), and Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 550 (1930).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28 (1).proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)
